description:
Anaplasma marginale is a tick-borne, obligate intracellular bacterium that infects and replicates within the red blood cells of cattle and other ruminants. It is the causative agent of bovine anaplasmosis, a disease characterized by hemolytic anemia, fever, decreased milk production, and potentially fatal outcomes in severe cases.

The bacterium belongs to the order Rickettsiales and the family Anaplasmataceae. Anaplasma marginale is primarily transmitted by various species of hard ticks, particularly those in the genus Dermacentor, through their saliva during the feeding process. Once inside the host's red blood cells, the bacteria divide and form inclusions known as "marginal bodies" along the periphery of the cells.

The disease caused by A. marginale can have significant economic impact on the cattle industry, particularly in regions where the bacterium is endemic. Effective control measures involve the use of antibiotic treatments, tick control strategies, and the development of vaccines to prevent and manage the spread of the infection.
